'''Ketevan''' "'''Katie'''" '''Melua''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɛ|l|uː|ə}};<ref>{{YouTube|LqY-rBM-eo0|"Katie Melua Interview at ARD Morgenmagazin Part I"}}</ref> {{lang-ka|ქეთევან "ქეთი" მელუა}}, {{IPA-ka|kʰɛtʰɛvɑn mɛluɑ|IPA}};<ref>Howard Isaac Aronson, ''Georgian. A Reading Grammar'', Columbus 1982, p. 18: "Stress in Georgian is extremely weak and has no effect on vowel quality. The stress is so weak that linguists have not been able to agree on exactly where it falls. In words of four and fewer syllables, the stress falls on either the initial syllable or the antepenultimate syllable (third from the end)."</ref> born 16 September 1984) is a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]]-[[British people|British]] singer and songwriter. She moved to the United Kingdom at the age of eight – first to [[Belfast]], and then to London in 1999.<ref name="Biog">{{cite web|author=Dramatico |title=biography |year=2003 |work=The Official Katie Melua website |url=http://www.katiemelua.com/biography.html |access-date=10 February 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110133730/http://www.katiemelua.com/biography.html |archive-date=10 January 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> Under the management of composer [[Mike Batt]], Melua is signed to the small [[Dramatico]] record label.<ref name="The hitman and her">{{cite news | first=Ariel |last=Leve| title=The hitman and her | work=[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]] | date=5 November 2006 | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2099-2430807,00.html | access-date =10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> She made her musical debut in 2003, and within three years was the United Kingdom's best-selling female artist<ref name="myvillage">{{cite web|first=Mandy |last=Carter |title=Interview: Katie Melua |work=MyVillage |date=1 August 2006 |url=http://london.myvillage.com/article/interview-katie-melua |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205064414/http://london.myvillage.com/article/interview-katie-melua |archive-date= 5 December 2010 |url-status=dead }}</ref> as well as Europe's highest selling European female artist.<ref>{{cite web | title=IFPI confirm Katie Melua as Europe's highest selling European female artist in 2006 | work=Press release | date=12 November 2006 | url=http://www.recordoftheday.com/cgi-bin/rotd-mb/rotd_config.pl?noframes;read=99599 | access-date=10 February 2010 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803140800/http://www.recordoftheday.com/cgi-bin/rotd-mb/rotd_config.pl?noframes%3Bread=99599 | archive-date=3 August 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>

In November 2003, at the age of 19, Melua released her first album, ''[[Call Off the Search]]'', which reached the top of the United Kingdom album charts and sold 1.8 million copies in its first five months of release.<ref>{{cite web | first= Johnny |last=Loftus | title= review of ''Call off the Search'' | work= allmusic | year=2004| url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r680628|pure_url=yes}} | access-date =10 February 2010}}</ref> Her second album, ''[[Piece by Piece (Katie Melua album)|Piece by Piece]]'', was released in September 2005 and {{As of|2006|alt=to date}} has gone platinum (one million units sold) four times.<ref>{{cite web | first=James Christopher |last=Monger | title= review of ''Piece by Piece'' | work= allmusic | year=2005| url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r806174|pure_url=yes}} | access-date =10 February 2010}}</ref> Melua released her third studio album ''[[Pictures (Katie Melua album)|Pictures]]'' in October 2007.<ref name="start afresh">{{cite news| first=Neil| last=McCormick| title=Katie Melua: I want to start afresh| date=15 September 2007| work=The Daily Telegraph| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2007/09/15/bmkatie115.xml| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018203625/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=%2Farts%2F2007%2F09%2F15%2Fbmkatie115.xml| url-status=dead| archive-date=18 October 2007| access-date=10 February 2010| location=London}}</ref>

According to the [[Sunday Times Rich List 2008]], Melua had amassed fortune of [[Pound sterling|£]]18 million, making her the seventh-richest British musician under the age of 30.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/katie-melua-worth-a-staggering-16318m-13876863.html |title=Katie Melua worth a staggering £18m |access-date=29 April 2008 |date=26 April 2008 |work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] |publisher=belfasttelegraph.co.uk }}</ref>

==Early life==

Ketevan Melua was born on 16 September 1984<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.noz.de/deutschland-welt/vermischtes/artikel/414805/katie-melua-liebt-deutsche-weihnachtsmarkte |title=Sängerin im Interview: Katie Melua liebt deutsche Weihnachtsmärkte |last=Tackenberg |first=Marcus |date=20 September 2013 |website=Neue Osnabrücker Zeitung |access-date=14 September 2019}}</ref> to Amiran and Tamara Melua<ref name="Rundschau 2020">{{cite web |last=Rundschau |first=Wuppertaler |title=ESC-Blog des Wuppertaler Musikexperten Peter Bergener: Katie Melua und ihre besondere Verbindung zu Wuppertal |website=Wuppertaler Rundschau |date=18 September 2020 |url=https://www.wuppertaler-rundschau.de/eurovision/katie-melua-und-ihre-besondere-verbindung-zu-wuppertal_aid-53450067 |language=de |access-date=30 November 2020}}</ref> in [[Kutaisi]], Georgia, which was then part of the [[Soviet Union]].<ref name="Georgia on her mind">{{cite news |first=Carl |last=Wilkinson |title=Georgia on her mind |work=The Observer |date=27 February 2005 |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/print/0,3858,5136283-102284,00.html |access-date=10 February 2010 |location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401035734/http://observer.guardian.co.uk/print/0,3858,5136283-102284,00.html |archive-date=1 April 2008 |url-status=dead}}</ref> She spent her first years with her grandparents in [[Tbilisi]]<ref name="Luxurious living">{{cite web |title=Melua Shuns Luxurious Living |date=10 May 2005 |work=contact music |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/xmlfeed.nsf/mndwebpages/melua%20shuns%20luxurious%20living |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref> before moving with her parents and brother to the town of [[Batumi]], where her father worked as a heart specialist.<ref name="Georgia on her mind" /> During this time, Melua sometimes had to carry buckets of water up five flights of stairs to her family's flat<ref name="I still shop at Oxfam">{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Billen |title=I still shop at Oxfam |work=The Times |date=24 January 2006 |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,14932-2006126,00.html |access-date=10 February 2010 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="Georgia peach">{{cite news |first=Katrina |last=Lobley |title=Georgia peach |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=27 May 2005 |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/Music/Georgia-peach/2005/05/26/1116950809567.html |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref> and according to her, "Now, when I'm staying in luxurious hotels, I think back to those days".<ref name="Luxurious living" />

In 1993, when Melua was eight, the family moved to [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]], in the aftermath of the [[Georgian Civil War]]. Her father, a heart surgeon, took up a position at the [[Royal Victoria Hospital, Belfast|Royal Victoria Hospital]]. The family remained in Belfast, living close to [[Falls Road (Belfast)|Falls Road]], until Melua was 14.<ref name="Allen 2020">{{cite news | last=Allen | first=Kelly | title=Northern Ireland so special to Katie Melua | website=The Belfast Telegraph | date=18 October 2020 | url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sunday-life/news/northern-ireland-so-special-to-katie-melua-39629088.html | access-date=30 November 2020}}</ref> During her time in Northern Ireland, Melua attended [[St Catherine's Primary School]] on the [[Falls Road, Belfast|Falls Road]] and later moved to [[Dominican College, Fortwilliam]].

The Melua family then moved to [[Sutton, London]] and some time later moved again to [[Redhill, Surrey]]. In 2008, Melua moved out of her parents' home in [[Maida Vale]] to an apartment in [[Notting Hill]],<ref name="The National" /> where she transformed the spare bedroom into a recording studio. Melua is fluent in English and speaks some Russian; despite still speaking her native Georgian fluently she has admitted that she cannot write songs in the language. Melua is also partly of [[Canadians|Canadian]]<ref>{{cite web |first=Stuart |last=Derdeyn |title=Katie Melua: Getting her own Piece of the pie |work=Vancouver Province |publisher=dose.ca |date=9 November 2006 |url=http://www.dose.ca/music/story.html?id=48b5560e-37d6-4800-8f56-f6b155ca838e&k=24656 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310122442/http://www.dose.ca/music/story.html?id=48b5560e-37d6-4800-8f56-f6b155ca838e&k=24656 |url-status=dead |archive-date=10 March 2007 |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref> and [[Russians|Russian]] ancestry.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_PQGJwEVVZM | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140622151741/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_PQGJwEVVZM| archive-date=2014-06-22 | url-status=dead|title=Katie Melua talks about the Georgia-Russia conflict |access-date=10 August 2008 |date=10 August 2008 |format=flash video |work=[[Ekstra Bladet]] |via=YouTube |quote=My grandmother is half Russia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/my-life-in-travel-katie-melua-526805.html |title=My Life in Travel: Katie Melua |date=26 February 2005 |work=The Independent |access-date=10 February 2010 |location=London |archive-date=2 August 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802063658/http://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/my-life-in-travel-katie-melua-526805.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>

Melua was baptised into the [[Georgian Orthodox Church]].<ref name="The National">{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/music/katie-melua-earned-success-on-her-own-terms |title=Success on her own terms |access-date=8 June 2008 |first=P |last=Kennedy |date=8 June 2008 |work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |publisher=Abu Dhabi Media Company}}</ref> When living in Belfast, Melua attended the [[Roman Catholic school]]s St Catherine's Primary School and [[Dominican College, Fortwilliam]], while her younger brother attended State schools.<ref name="Biog" /> After completing her [[GCSE]]s at the all-girls' grammar school [[Nonsuch High School]] in [[Cheam]], [[London Borough of Sutton|Sutton]], Melua attended the [[BRIT School]] for the Performing Arts in the [[London Borough of Croydon]], undertaking a [[Business And Technology Education Council (BTEC)|BTEC]] with an A-level in music.<ref name="BBC3243501">{{cite news |title=New Music: Katie Melua |work=BBC News |date=10 November 2003 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/3243501.stm |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref>

==Nationality==

On 10 August 2005, just before she turned 21, Melua became a [[British nationality law|British citizen]] along with her parents and brother. The citizenship ceremony took place in [[Weybridge]], Surrey.<ref name="British citizen">{{cite news | title= Singer Melua made British citizen |work=BBC News | date=11 August 2005| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4140802.stm }}</ref> Becoming a British citizen meant that Melua had held three citizenships before she was 21; first Soviet, then [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] and finally, British.

After the ceremony, Melua stated her pride at her newest nationality. "As a family, we have been very fortunate to find a happy lifestyle in this country and we feel we belong. We still consider ourselves to be Georgian, because that is where our roots are, and I return to Georgia every year to see my uncles and grandparents, but I am proud to now be a British citizen".<ref name="British citizen"/>

==Personal life==

Melua has been referred to as an '[[adrenaline junkie]]' because she enjoys [[roller coaster]]s and [[funfair]]s and often [[paragliding|paraglides]] and [[Hang gliding|hang glides]].<ref>{{cite web| title=I'm The Closest Thing To Crazy| work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]| first=Rick |last=Fulton |date=24 September 2005| url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/I%27m+the+closest+thing+to+crazy%3B+Katie+Melua+reveals+her+secret+as+a...-a0136582327l| access-date =10 February 2010}}</ref> She has [[Parachuting|skydived]] four times and taken several [[Aviator|flying lesson]]s, and in 2004 she was lowered from a {{Convert|200|m|adj=on}} building in New Zealand at {{Convert|60|mph|abbr=on}}. When asked about Melua being an 'adrenaline junkie', Mike Batt said, "she enjoys extremes, but in life her emotions are always in check".<ref name="The hitman and her" /> In November 2009, Melua nearly drowned while diving in a lake near [[Heathrow Airport]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Singer Katie Melua plays down diving 'fright' |agency=[[BBC News]] |date=4 December 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8394785.stm| access-date= 10 February 2010 }}</ref>

In September 2010, Melua was ordered by her doctors to stop working for a few months after suffering a [[Mental breakdown|nervous breakdown]], resulting in her hospitalisation for six weeks. As a result, all touring and promotional activities were postponed until the following year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua cancels everything this year |publisher=Eventnews.se|date=4 October 2010 |url=http://www.eventnews.se#101004| access-date= 4 October 2010 }}</ref>

Melua opened up about the breakdown years later in an interview with ''[[The Independent]]'', saying that it ended up being one of the best things that had ever happened to her, as she said it helped to quash a feeling of superiority she felt by being a successful musician in the music industry. "....It was petrifying, but it put a stop to fantasies of being able to do anything. The oddest thing about this job is the sense of superiority you get. It was a huge wake-up call. I was completely out of it for two weeks, and in hospital for six. There was a bunch of things going on, things at home and crazy work schedules, and you really believe the world revolved around you and it doesn't."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lister|first1=David|title=Katie Melua interview: 'The oddest thing about this job is the sense of superiority you get'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/katie-melua-in-winter-gori-womens-choir-a7354366.html|website=The Independent|date=14 October 2016|access-date=17 October 2016}}</ref>

In January 2012, Melua confirmed her [[engagement]] to [[Superbike World Championship|World Superbike]] racer and musician [[James Toseland]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Katie Melua's Delight Over Engagement | work=Contactmusic.com | date=18 January 2012 | url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news/katie-meluas-delight-over-engagement_1284567 | access-date =19 January 2012}}</ref> The couple married on 1 September 2012 in the Nash Conservatory at the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Royal Botanic Gardens]] in [[Kew]], southwest London.<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua marries superbike champion James Toseland |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-news/katie-melua-marries-superbike-champion-james-toseland-8101182.html |access-date=25 April 2020 |work=Evening Standard |date=2 September 2012 |language=en}}</ref> A 2020 interview with the national Swedish news agency TT revealed that the couple had separated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vk.se/2020-08-29/katie-melua-ville-inte-gora-en-skilsmassoskiva|title=Katie Melua: Ville inte göra en skilsmässoskiva|date=29 August 2020|website=Vk.se|access-date=16 October 2020}}</ref> Interviewed on ITV's ''Lorraine'' live from West London on 16 October 2020, Melua confirmed that the couple had divorced."<ref>{{Cite web|date=15 October 2020|title=Telegraph Album No8 Katie Melua|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/artists/katie-melua-album-no-8-review-admirable-divorce-album-no-need/amp/#aoh=16028368998948&csi=1&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201018151042/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/artists/katie-melua-album-no-8-review-admirable-divorce-album-no-need/amp/ |archive-date=2020-10-18 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live}}</ref>

In August 2022, Melua announced that she is pregnant with her first child.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Soguksu |first=Ayla |date=2022-08-04 |title=Katie Melua announces pregnancy as she debuts baby bump during European tour |url=https://www.ok.co.uk/celebrity-news/breaking-katie-melua-pregnant-baby-27653614 |access-date= |website=OK! Magazine |language=en}}</ref>

==Career==

===Early stage===

After an upbringing in politically unstable Georgia, Melua initially planned to become either a historian or a politician.<ref>{{cite web | title= Katie Melua in Gunfire Drama | work= Female First | date=11 May 2005| url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/music/musicnews/Katie+Melua-4741.html }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title= Second Cup Café: Katie Melua | work=[[CBS News]] | date=8 July 2006| agency=(CBS/AP) | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/06/earlyshow/saturday/secondcup/main1781990.shtml | access-date =10 February 2010}}</ref> This changed in 2000, at the age of 15, when Melua took part in a talent competition on British television channel [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] called "Stars Up Their Noses" (a spoof of ''[[Stars in Their Eyes]]'') as part of the children's programme ''[[Mad for It]]''.<ref>{{cite web | first= Courtney | last= Grimes | title= 'The Closest Thing to Crazy': An Interview With UK Rocker Katie Melua | work= Epiphone | date= 19 July 2005 | url= http://www.epiphone.com/news.asp?NewsID=313 | access-date= 10 February 2010 | url-status= dead | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100202185140/http://epiphone.com/news.asp?NewsID=313 | archive-date= 2 February 2010 | df= dmy-all }}</ref> Melua won the contest by singing [[Badfinger]]'s "[[Without You (Badfinger song)|Without You]]". The prize was £350 worth of [[MFI Retail|MFI]] vouchers, with which she bought a chair for her father.<ref>{{cite web | title= Melua trivia page | work= Biography channel | year= 2005 | url= http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_facts/1500:1707:1/Katie_Melua.htm | access-date= 10 February 2010 | url-status= dead | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090606044946/http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_facts/1500%3A1707%3A1/Katie_Melua.htm | archive-date= 6 June 2009 | df= dmy-all }}</ref> Had she lost the contest, she would have been [[gunge]]d.<ref>{{cite web|title=Video of the performance show on Belgian TV |work=YouTube |date=23 November 2006 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAyoaezBa_o |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505051535/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAyoaezBa_o |archive-date=5 May 2008 }}</ref>

===BRIT School and Mike Batt===

After completing her [[General Certificate of Secondary Education|GCSEs]], Melua attended the [[BRIT School]] for the Performing Arts in the [[London Borough of Croydon]], undertaking a [[Business And Technology Education Council (BTEC)|BTEC]] with an A-level in music. When studying at the school, Melua began to write songs and met her future manager and producer, [[Mike Batt]].<ref name=BBC3243501/>

While performing at BRIT School showcase, Melua caught the eye of songwriter and producer Mike Batt. Batt was originally looking for an acid-rock band, bass player<ref>{{cite web | title=Katie in Iceland | work= dagskra.ruv.is | year=2007| url=http://dagskra.ruv.is/streaming/sjonvarpid/?file=4365539/2 | access-date= 10 February 2010}}</ref> and a singer capable of singing "jazz and blues in an interesting way".<ref>{{cite web | first=Mike | last=Batt | author-link=Mike Batt | title=Katie Melua | work=dramatico site | year=2003 | url=http://www.dramatico.com/artists.html | access-date=10 February 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070113215928/http://www.dramatico.com/artists.html | archive-date=13 January 2007 | url-status=dead | df=dmy-all }}</ref> After hearing Melua sing "Faraway Voice" (a song she wrote about the death of her idol [[Eva Cassidy]]) Batt signed the 18-year-old Melua to his small [[Dramatico]] recording and management company and took her into the studio, producing her first three albums during the subsequent years, plus her fifth and sixth albums.<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua: A Debut With a Familiar Refrain |first=Richard |last=Harrington |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=16 June 2004 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A44922-2004Jun15.html |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref>

===William Orbit===

For her fourth album, ''[[The House (Katie Melua album)|The House]]'' (2010), Melua worked with producer [[William Orbit]]. She said about the experience: "The whole thing has been really exciting. It was the same feeling I had the first time I went skydiving. I was really quite nervous, but I knew all I had to do was let myself go and it was going to feel amazing. I wasn't trying to get away from anything. It was more about going towards something. I wanted the music to be inspired by the future, something unknown that's never been heard before, but at the same time hold on to the values of the music of the past, to try and tap into something that's so ancient and old that it's kind of forgotten. I thought that, if we went far enough in both directions, we could end up in the same place".<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/7682828/Katie-Melua-interview.html Katie Melua interview], Daily Telegraph, Neil McCormick, 5 May 2010</ref>

==Recordings==

[[File:Katie Melua at signing.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Melua at a signing in 2004]]

===''Call off the Search'' (2003)===

{{Main|Call Off the Search}}

Melua's debut album, ''[[Call Off the Search]]'', was released on 3 November 2003 and featured two songs written by Melua: "Belfast (Penguins and Cats)", a song about Melua's experience of her time in the troubled capital of [[Northern Ireland]], and "Faraway Voice", a song about the death of [[Eva Cassidy]]. Melua also covered songs by [[Delores J. Silver]] ("[[Learnin' the Blues]]"), [[John Mayall]] ("[[Crawling up a Hill]]"), [[Randy Newman]] ("[[I Think It's Going to Rain Today]]") and [[James Shelton (songwriter)|James Shelton]] ("Lilac Wine", originally a UK hit for singer [[Elkie Brooks]]). The other six songs on the album were by Mike Batt.<ref>{{cite web | first= Johnny |last=Loftus | title= "Call off the Search" Review | work=allmusic | year=2003| url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r680628|pure_url=yes}} | access-date= 10 February 2010}}</ref>

It was initially difficult for Melua and Batt to obtain airplay for the album's lead single, the Mike Batt song  "[[The Closest Thing to Crazy]]". This changed when [[BBC Radio 2]] producer [[Paul Walters]] heard the single and played it on the popular Sir [[Terry Wogan]] breakfast show.<ref>{{cite news | first=Andrew |last=Purcell | title= Talk the talk |work=The Guardian | date=11 August 2006| url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,,1841267,00.html | access-date= 10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Wogan played "The Closest Thing to Crazy" frequently in the summer of 2003. Wogan's support raised Melua's profile and when ''[[Call Off the Search]]'' was released in November 2003 supported by a TV campaign financed by Batt, it entered the top 40 UK albums chart. The single achieved the number 10 spot in the UK chart. After an appearance on the Royal Variety Show the album was further boosted and Batt continued a relentless marketing campaign which saw the album hit the number one spot in January 2004.  ''Call Off the Search'' reached the top five in Ireland, top 20 in Norway and top 30 in a composite European chart. In the UK the album sold 1.9 million copies, making it six times [[platinum record|platinum]], and spent six weeks at the top of the UK charts. It sold 3.6 million copies worldwide. Subsequent singles from the album did not repeat the success of the first – the second single and album title track "[[Call Off the Search (song)|Call Off the Search]]" reached number 19, and the third single "[[Crawling up a Hill]]" got to number 41.<ref>{{cite web | title= Melua Profile | work= purevolume | url= http://www.purevolume.com/katiemelua | access-date= 10 February 2010 | archive-url= https://www.webcitation.org/5mq2NBmvw?url=http://www.purevolume.com/KatieMelua | archive-date= 17 January 2010 | url-status= dead | df= dmy-all }}</ref> The album achieved 6× platinum status in UK, 3× platinum in Norway, 2× platinum in Germany, Holland, Denmark and Ireland, Platinum in South Africa, Australia and Switzerland and gold (500,000 units sold) in New Zealand and Hong Kong.

===''Piece by Piece'' (2005)===

{{Main|Piece by Piece (Katie Melua album)}}

Melua's second album, ''[[Piece by Piece (Katie Melua album)|Piece by Piece]]'', was released on 26 September 2005. Its [[lead single]] was the Mike Batt song, "[[Nine Million Bicycles]]", which was released a week before the album on 19 September and was number three in the UK singles chart. The album contains four more songs written by Melua herself, four more by Batt (including "Nine Million Bicycles"), one Batt/Melua collaboration and three more songs described as new versions of "great songs". The band line-up was the same as on the first album. The album debuted at the number one spot on the [[UK Albums Chart]] in the week of 3 October 2005.<ref>{{cite news | title= Katie Melua makes mellow comeback |work=BBC News | date=26 September 2005| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4268288.stm | access-date= 10 February 2010}}</ref> This album broke Melua across Europe where it sold 1 million copies in Germany alone and achieved the number one position in Billboard's "European" albums chart. It was 4× platinum in UK and Ireland, 3× platinum in Norway, Denmark, Holland and Germany, 2× platinum in Poland and Switzerland and at least platinum or gold in France, Iceland, South Africa, Austria, Belgium, New Zealand and Sweden. Worldwide sales to date are in excess of 3.5 million.

On 30 September 2005, Melua came under criticism in ''[[The Guardian]]'' from writer and scientist [[Simon Singh]] for the lyrics (written by Mike Batt) of the track "Nine Million Bicycles". Batt's disputed lyrics were:
{{blockquote|text=We are 12 billion light-years from the edge. That's a guess – no-one can ever say it's true, but I know that I will always be with you.<ref name="YouTube">{{YouTube|id=2JMFiBwcVyQ|title=Michael Shermer vs. Katie Melua}}</ref>}}
They were interpreted by Singh as an assault on the accuracy of the work of cosmologists<ref>{{cite news | first=Simon |last=Singh |author-link=Simon Singh| title= Katie Melua's bad science |work=The Guardian | date=30 September 2005| url=https://www.theguardian.com/g2/story/0,3604,1581445,00.html | access-date= 10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> which sparked a series of letters from other ''Guardian'' readers, agreeing or disagreeing.<ref>{{cite news | first=Mike |last=Batt |author-link =Mike Batt| title= A few million light years short of reality |work=The Guardian | date=6 October 2005| url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,,1585880,00.html | access-date= 10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> On 15 October, Melua and Singh appeared on the [[BBC]]'s [[Today programme|''Today'' programme]], and Melua light-heartedly performed the song during the interview, including Singh's tongue-in-cheek amendments to the lyrics:
{{blockquote|text=We are 13.7 billion light-years from the edge of the observable universe / That's a good estimate with well-defined error bars / And with the available information / I predict that I will always be with you.<ref name=YouTube/>}}
Both sides amicably agreed that the new lyrics were less likely to achieve commercial success, amidst a discussion about [[Science|scientific accuracy]] versus [[artistic licence]]. Melua said that she "should have known better" because she used to be a member of the [[astronomy club]] at school.<ref>{{cite web | title= Today Program | work=[[BBC Radio 4]] | date=15 October 2005 | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/today/listenagain/ram/today1_melua_20051015.ram | access-date= 10 February 2010}}</ref>

A [[double A-side]] of the Melua-penned "[[I Cried for You (Katie Melua song)|I Cried for You]]" and a cover of [[The Cure]]'s "[[Just Like Heaven (The Cure song)|Just Like Heaven]]" (1988), which also appeared on the soundtrack to the film ''[[Just Like Heaven (film)|Just Like Heaven]]'',<ref>{{cite web | first=Rebecca | last=Murray | title="Just Like Heaven" Movie Soundtrack News | work=About Movies | date=22 August 2005 | url=http://movies.about.com/od/justlikeheaven/a/heaven082205.htm | access-date=10 February 2010 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306221517/http://movies.about.com/od/justlikeheaven/a/heaven082205.htm | archive-date=6 March 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> was released in the UK on 5 December and peaked at number 35. "I Cried for You" was inspired by a meeting with the writer of ''[[Holy Blood, Holy Grail]]''.<ref>{{cite web | first= R.J. |last=Carter | title= Ingénue Rising | work= Critical Blast | date= 14 June 2006| url=http://www.criticalblast.com/articles/2006/06/14/katie-melua-ingenue-rising| access-date= 10 February 2010}}</ref>

A third single, "[[Spider's Web (single)|Spider's Web]]" was released on 17 April 2006 and peaked at number 52 in the UK. Melua embarked on a concert tour in support of ''Piece by Piece'', the UK leg of which started in Aberdeen, Scotland on 20 January 2006.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview |work=teen today |date=January 2006 |url=http://www.teentoday.co.uk/music/musicinterviews/katiemelua.shtml |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090804141114/http://www.teentoday.co.uk/music/musicinterviews/katiemelua.shtml |archive-date=4 August 2009 }}</ref> Towards the end of 2006, Melua released the single, "[[It's Only Pain]]", which was written by [[Mike Batt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katiemelua.com/releases/itsonlypain.html |title=It's Only Pain |author=Dramatico |date=11 September 2006 |work=The Official Katie Melua Website |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128140638/http://www.katiemelua.com/releases/itsonlypain.html |archive-date=28 January 2010 }}</ref> This was followed by the release of "[[Shy Boy (Katie Melua song)|Shy Boy]]", also written by Batt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katiemelua.com/releases/shyboy.html |title=Shy Boy |author=Dramatico |date=20 November 2006 |work=The Official Katie Melua Website |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207201100/http://www.katiemelua.com/releases/shyboy.html |archive-date=7 February 2009 }}</ref>

===''Pictures'' (2007)===

[[File:KatieMeluaCambridge2006Tour.jpg|270px|thumb|right|Melua at Cambridge Corn Exchange, part of her 2006 UK concert tour]]

{{Main|Pictures (Katie Melua album)}}

Melua's third album, ''[[Pictures (Katie Melua album)|Pictures]]'', was released in the UK on 1 October 2007<ref>{{cite web | first= Maureen |last=Coleman| title= Katie true to her heart on new album| date=19 July 2007| work= [[The Belfast Telegraph]]| url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/katie-true-to-her-heart-on-new-album-13460011.html | access-date= 10 February 2010}}</ref> and was announced to be, at least temporarily, the last of her albums in collaboration with Mike Batt as lead writer and producer.<ref name="start afresh"/> It also features Melua's friend Molly McQueen, the former frontwoman of [[The Faders]], as co-writer of "Perfect Circle". Melua also collaborated with [[Andrea McEwan]] on the album, who wrote the lyrics for "What I Miss About You" and "Dirty Dice".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hangout.altsounds.com/features/103634-q-and-a-interview-with-andrea-mcewan.html |title=Q&A Interview with Andrea McEwan |date=1 December 2008 |work=alt sounds |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100131104740/http://hangout.altsounds.com/features/103634-q-and-a-interview-with-andrea-mcewan.html |archive-date=31 January 2010 }}</ref> The album also featured a cover of "[[In My Secret Life]]" by [[Leonard Cohen]] and [[Sharon Robinson (songwriter)|Sharon Robinson]]. Melua said of the cover, "[It] completely got to me, about how we all have great ideals but in reality we end up conforming, following everyone else."<ref name="start afresh"/>

Melua released four singles from the album: "[[If You Were a Sailboat]]", "[[Mary Pickford (Used to Eat Roses)|Mary Pickford]]", "[[If the Lights Go Out]]", and "Ghost Town".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katiemelua.com/music.html |title=Katie Melua singles |author=Dramatico |access-date=10 February 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127103942/http://www.katiemelua.com/music.html |archive-date=27 January 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> "Mary Pickford", written by Mike Batt, was about the [[silent film]] star [[Mary Pickford|of the same name]] and the formation of United Artists along with Charlie Chaplin, D W Griffith and Douglas Fairbanks .{{citation needed|date=April 2020}} "Ghost Town" was Melua's first [[reggae]]-sounding song.<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua at the O2 Arena |first= Lisa |last=Verrico |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date= 10 November 2008|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/live_reviews/article5118749.ece |access-date=10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref>

The [[iTunes]] version of the album includes a cover of the [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] song "[[Under the Cherry Moon]]" as a bonus track.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katiemelua.com/songlyrics/underthecherrymoon.html |title=Under the Cherry Moon |work=The Official Katie Melua website |publisher=Dramatico |access-date=10 February 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100228083445/http://www.katiemelua.com/songlyrics/underthecherrymoon.html |archive-date=28 February 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref>

===''The House'' (2010)===

{{Main|The House (Katie Melua album)}}

Melua's fourth album, ''[[The House (Katie Melua album)|The House]]'', was released on 24 May 2010. Songwriters include [[Lauren Christy]], [[Guy Chambers]] and [[Rick Nowels]], with [[William Orbit]] producing.<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua announces tour dates |newspaper=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] |date=20 January 2010 |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/entertainment/katie-melua-announces-tour-dates-14644541.html |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.themusicfix.co.uk/content/news-flash/9477/in-the-house-with-katie-melua.html |title=In ''The House'' with Katie Melua |author=Colin Polonowski |date=17 March 2010 |work=The Music Fix |access-date=17 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417005635/http://www.themusicfix.co.uk/content/news-flash/9477/in-the-house-with-katie-melua.html |archive-date=17 April 2010 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

===''Secret Symphony'' (2012)===

{{Main|Secret Symphony (Katie Melua album)}}

Melua's fifth studio album, ''[[Secret Symphony (Katie Melua album)|Secret Symphony]]'' was released on 5 March 2012 and also debuted high in the UK album chart. The album was produced, arranged and conducted by Mike Batt. Melua said in a statement: "This album was going to be my 'singer's album'. I had always wanted to do this one day; singing other people's songs brings something out of you and your voice that isn't perhaps where you would have gone vocally with your own material."<ref>{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Lewis|title=Katie Melua announces new album 'Secret Symphony'|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a339406/katie-melua-announces-new-album-secret-symphony.html|work=Digital SPy|date=8 September 2011|publisher=Hearst Magazines UK|access-date=6 March 2012}}</ref>

===''Ketevan'' (2013)===
{{unreferenced section|date=September 2022}}
{{Main|Ketevan (album)}}

[[File:Katie Melua (ZMF 2016) jm63614.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Zelt-Musik-Festival]] 2016 in [[Freiburg]], Germany]]

Melua's sixth studio album, ''[[Ketevan (album)|Ketevan]]'', was released on 16 September 2013. It was co-produced by Mike Batt and his son, singer-songwriter Luke Batt, both of whom contributed songs, separately and in collaboration with Melua. When ''Ketevan'' entered the UK charts at number 6, Melua joined a very small group of female artists, which includes Madonna and Kate Bush, who have scored six consecutive UK top 10 studio albums. ''Ketevan'' also entered the top 10 in France, Poland, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland in its first week of release.

===''In Winter'' (2016)===

{{main|In Winter}}

[[File:Cwo 20181121213304a Katie Melua, Gori Women's Choir.jpg|thumb|Melua with the [[Gori Women's Choir]], 2018]]

Melua's seventh album, ''[[In Winter]]'', was released on 14 October 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maverick-country.com/new-album-winter-katie-melua-featuring-gori-womens-choir-released-october-14/ |title=New album IN WINTER from Katie Melua featuring the Gori Women's Choir to be released October 14 |work=Maverick |date=9 September 2016 |access-date=14 September 2016 |author=Barnett, Lauren}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.frontview-magazine.be/en/news/katie-melua-announces-new-album-in-winter|title=Katie Melua announces new album 'In Winter'! |work=Front View Magazine |date=28 August 2016 |access-date=14 September 2016}}</ref> For this record, Melua went back to her native [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] to record an album with the [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]] Women's Choir, a native Georgian all-woman singing troupe. Melua revealed during an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'' that her partnership with Mike Batt had come to an end after her last album, as it was a six-album deal with Batt's Dramatico records.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hickling|first1=Alfred|title='Stalin sent granddad to Siberia': Katie Melua Goes Home to Georgia|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/aug/17/katie-melua-georgia-gori-womens-choir|date=17 August 2016|website=The Guardian|access-date=21 August 2016}}</ref>

In 2017, she released a cover version of "[[Fields of Gold]]", the official song for [[Children in Need]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://completemusicupdate.com/article/katie-melua-covers-stings-fields-of-gold-for-children-in-need/|title=Katie Melua covers Sting’s Fields Of Gold for Children In Need|last=Malt|first=Andy|date=3 November 2017|work=Complete Music Update|access-date=10 October 2022}}</ref>

===''Album No. 8'' (2020)===

In June 2020, Melua supported the Georgian Red Cross Society in their efforts to assist the vulnerable population in Georgia during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] by performing a live charity concert featuring songs that were requested by her followers on her social media accounts.<ref>{{cite web |title=Singer Katie Melua to host live show in support of Georgian Red Cross Society |url=https://agenda.ge/en/news/2020/1971 |website=Agenda.ge |access-date=30 June 2020 |date=22 June 2020}}</ref> Melua released her eighth studio album, ''[[Album No. 8]]'', on 16 October 2020. The lead single off the album, "A Love like That", which was produced by [[Leo Abrahams]],<ref name="melua2020">{{cite web |title=Katie Melua is back with new music video |url=https://www.totalntertainment.com/music/katie-melua-is-back-with-new-music-video/ |website=Total NTertainment |access-date=30 June 2020 |date=30 June 2020}}</ref> received its first airplay on 30 June 2020 on [[BBC Radio 2]]. The video for the song features British actor [[Billy Howle]] and was directed by Charlie Lightening,<ref name="melua2020"/> who has directed videos for the likes of [[Paul McCartney]], [[Jamiroquai]] and [[Liam Gallagher]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Braithwaite |first1=Andrew |title=Katie Melua is back with relaxed, epic & cinematic 'A Love Like That' - Watch |url=https://musictalkers.com/reviews/6985-katie-melua-is-back-with-relaxed,-epic-cinematic-%E2%80%98a-love-like-that%E2%80%99-watch |website=Music Talkers |access-date=30 June 2020 |date=30 June 2020}}</ref> The second single, "Airtime" premiered on 24 July 2020. The video for 'Airtime', which again featured actor Billy Howle and was also directed by Charlie Lightning, was shot around [[Herne Bay]] over two days and was filmed according to COVID-19 lockdown guidelines.<ref>{{cite web |title='Airtime' released by Katie Melua in advance of Album No. 8 |url=https://www.mags4dorset.co.uk/airtime-released-by-katie-melua-in-advance-of-album-no-8/#.XzdW8-hKiUk |access-date=15 August 2020 |date=27 July 2020}}</ref>

==Other work==

===Acting and modelling===

Melua appeared in a segment of the 2007 film ''[[Grindhouse (film)|Grindhouse]]'', written by [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Robert Rodriguez]]. The segment in which Melua appeared, entitled "[[Don't (grindhouse film)|Don't]]", was a faux trailer, directed by [[Edgar Wright]] and produced in the style of a 1970s' [[Hammer House of Horror]] film trailer.<ref>{{cite web|first=Katie |last=Melua |title=Latest Blog – 7 March 2007 |publisher=MySpace |date=7 March 2007 |url=http://www.katiemelua.com/blog2007.html |access-date=10 February 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111044500/http://www.katiemelua.com/blog2007.html |archive-date=11 January 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref>

In 2009, Melua was named as the new face of the leading French cashmere designer, [[Éric Bompard]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua named as the face of Eric Bompard cashmere |first=Kimberly |last=Thrower |work=The Daily Telegraph  |date=13 August 2009 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/fashionnews/6021659/Katie-Melua-named-as-the-face-of-Eric-Bompard-cashmere.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090816160526/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/fashionnews/6021659/Katie-Melua-named-as-the-face-of-Eric-Bompard-cashmere.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=16 August 2009 |access-date=10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref>

===World record holder===

On 2 October 2006, Melua entered the ''[[Guinness Book of Records]]'' for playing the deepest underwater concert 303 metres below sea level on the Norwegian [[Statoil]]'s [[Troll A platform]] in the [[North Sea]]. Melua and her band underwent extensive medical tests and survival training in Norway before flying by helicopter to the rig.

Melua later described achieving the record as "the most surreal gig I have ever done".<ref>{{cite news | title= Melua's deep sea gig sets record |work=BBC News | date= 2 October 2006| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/5396970.stm |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref> Melua's concert is commemorated in the DVD release ''Concert Under the Sea'', released in June 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Katie Melua's concert under the sea |first=Veronica |last=Schmidt |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date= 24 May 2007|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article1829026.ece |access-date=10 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref>

===Charity work===

In November 2004 Melua was asked to take part in [[Band Aid 20]] in which she joined a chorus of British and Irish pop singers to create a rendition of "[[Do They Know It's Christmas?]]" to raise money for famine relief in Africa.<ref>{{cite news | title= Geldof hails new Band Aid single |work=BBC News | date= 15 November 2004| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4008039.stm |access-date=10 February 2010 | first=Ian | last=Youngs}}</ref> Then in March 2005, Melua sang "[[Too Much Love Will Kill You]]" with [[Brian May]] at the [[46664 (concerts)|46664]] concert in [[George, South Africa]] for [[Nelson Mandela]]'s HIV charity. Melua had been a fan of [[Queen (band)|Queen]] since her childhood in Georgia when her uncles played the band's music, so performing with May was a realisation of a childhood dream.<ref name="Georgia peach"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Queen And Katie Melua Team Up |work=Female First |date=10 March 2005 |url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/entertainment/34042004.html |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802101940/http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/entertainment/34042004.html |archive-date=2 August 2009 }}</ref> Later in 2005, through her role as a [[goodwill ambassador]] to the charity [[Save the Children]], Melua went to [[Sri Lanka]] where she observed the work the charity was doing for children in the area after the [[Sri Lankan civil war|civil war]] and [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|Indian Ocean tsunami]].<ref>{{cite web | first=Katie | last=Melua | title=Katie Melua in Sri Lanka | work=[[Save the Children]] | date=15 June 2005 | url=http://www.savethechildren.org.uk/en/55_1399.htm | access-date=10 February 2010 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009100001/http://www.savethechildren.org.uk/en/55_1399.htm | archive-date=9 October 2007 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2006 Melua donated all the proceeds from her single "[[Spider's Web (song)|Spider's Web]]" to the charity.<ref>{{cite web | title= Melua To Donate Single Proceeds To Charity | work=contact music | date=11 April 2006 | url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/xmlfeed.nsf/mndwebpages/melua%20to%20donate%20single%20proceeds%20to%20charity_11_04_2006 | access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref>

On 7 July 2007, Melua performed at the [[Live Earth concert, Hamburg|German leg]] of [[Live Earth]] in Hamburg<ref>{{cite web | first=Maureen |last=Coleman | title= Katie sings to save the planet | work=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] | date= 5 July 2007| url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/live-earth/article2737816.ece| archive-url=https://archive.today/20080116113210/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/live-earth/article2737816.ece| url-status=dead| archive-date=16 January 2008|access-date=10 February 2010 }}</ref> and in December of that year, Melua released a cover of the [[Louis Armstrong]] song "[[What a Wonderful World]]" in which she sang with a recording of the late [[Eva Cassidy]]. All profits from the single, which entered the UK singles chart at No. 1 on 16 December 2007, went to the [[Red Cross]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Melua duet headed for number one |work=BBC News | date= 12 December 2007| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7140478.stm| access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref>

Melua has visited [[Oxfam]] charity shops for many years, using them frequently to buy her clothing.<ref name="I still shop at Oxfam"/> She has stated that this is related as much to her dislike of spending and glamour as it is to her support for the charity,<ref name="Georgia peach"/> and admits that she looks "like a [[tramp]]" and that her hairdresser playfully calls her look "the Romanian window cleaner".<ref>{{cite web | title= I Look like a tramp | work= contact music | date=20 September 2005| url=http://excite.contactmusic.com/new/xmlfeed.nsf/mndwebpages/melua%20i%20look%20like%20a%20tramp |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref>

Melua is a patron of Fair Trees, the organisation that is trying to stop exploitation of cone pickers in [[Ambrolauri]], Georgia, by the European Christmas tree industry. The local people in this region of Georgia are paid a pittance to risk their lives climbing 30 m high [[fir]] trees to collect the [[Conifer cone|cones]] from which the seeds are extracted and sent to Christmas tree nurseries in Europe. Until Fair Trees came along these cone pickers were given no safety equipment or training, no health insurance and very little pay; every year people are injured and even killed doing this work. Fair Trees grow and sell the only fair trade Christmas trees in the world (certified by the WFTO).

Melua is a patron of the Manx Cancer Help charity, which offers support to cancer sufferers and is based on the Isle of Man. She attended the 2013 fundraising ball for the charity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iomtoday.co.im/news/isle-of-man-news/company-announces-its-charity-of-the-year-1-6407282 |title=Company announces its charity of the year – Isle of Man Today |publisher=Iomtoday.co.im |date=30 January 2014 |access-date=27 June 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426105401/http://www.iomtoday.co.im/news/isle-of-man-news/company-announces-its-charity-of-the-year-1-6407282 |archive-date=26 April 2014}}</ref>

===Musical influences===

Melua has stated that the rock band [[Queen (band)|Queen]] were a huge influence on her as a child/teenager, with one of her memories of music being her uncle playing records by Queen and [[Led Zeppelin]].<ref>{{cite news |title=How Melua found her voice |first=Joe |last=Jackson |newspaper=[[Irish Independent]] |date=1 October 2006 |access-date =10 February 2010 |url=http://www.independent.ie/unsorted/features/how-melua-found-her-voice-135349.html }}</ref> She performed with Queen at the [[46664 (concerts)|46664]] concert in South Africa in March 2005.<ref>{{cite news |title=Stars unite for Mandela concert |agency =[[BBC News]] |date=20 March 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4364103.stm |access-date =10 February 2010}}</ref>

Melua appeared on the [[BBC]]'s ''[[The Culture Show]]'' in November 2006 advocating [[Paul McCartney]] as her choice in the search for Britain's greatest living icon.<ref>{{cite web | first=Katie |last=Melua | title=Living Icons |work=BBC |date=November 2006 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/livingicons/bio07.shtml |access-date=10 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Katie |last=Melua |title=Katie Melua Talks About Paul McCartney |work=BBC |publisher=YouTube |date=25 January 2007 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ICIXDJ0G9ok |access-date=10 February 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907011510/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ICIXDJ0G9ok |archive-date=7 September 2014 }}</ref>
